title: 103_hr982
content:
The Act may be cited as the "World University Games Commemorative Coin Act of 1993". Coin specifications are outlined in the Act. The Secretary of the Treasury will issue up to 200,000 five-dollar gold coins and up to 750,000 one-dollar silver coins with specific specifications and designs commemorating American athletes in the World University Games. The Secretary of the Treasury will issue up to 200,000 five-dollar gold coins and up to 750,000 one-dollar silver coins with specific specifications and designs commemorating American athletes in the World University Games. The one-dollar coins will weigh 26.73 grams, have a diameter of 1.500 inches, and contain 90 percent silver and 10 percent copper. The design of the dollar coins will be emblematic of American athletes' participation in the games, with inscriptions of the year "1993", "Liberty", "In God We Trust", "United States of America", and "E Pluribus Unum". The coins will be legal tender. SEC. 3. The Secretary will obtain silver for coins from stockpiles under the Strategic and Critical Materials Stock Piling Act and gold under existing law. SEC. 4. The design for each coin will be selected by the Secretary in consultation with specific entities. SEC. 5. The coins will be sold. SEC. 5. SALE OF THE COINS.

The coins will be sold by the Secretary at face value plus the cost of designing and issuing them. Bulk sales will be offered at a discount, and prepaid orders will be accepted with a reasonable discount. A surcharge of $35 per coin for five-dollar coins and $7 per coin for one-dollar coins will be included in all sales. SEC. 6. ISSUANCE OF THE COINS.

The five-dollar coins will be issued in uncirculated and proof qualities at the United States Bullion Depository at West Point. The one-dollar coins may be issued in uncirculated and proof qualities, with only one facility of the United States Mint used for each quality. The coins authorized under this Act may be issued starting on July 1, 1993, and minting will cease after June 30, 1994. SEC. 7. GENERAL WAIVER OF PROCUREMENT REGULATIONS. No procurement laws apply to goods or services for this Act. Compliance with equal employment laws is required for contracts under this Act.

SEC. 8. DISTRIBUTION OF SURCHARGES. Surcharges from coin sales go to the Greater Buffalo Athletic Corporation for local athletic programs and facilities.

SEC. 9. AUDITS. SEC. 9. AUDITS. The Comptroller General can examine the Greater Buffalo Athletic Corporation's records related to expenditures. SEC. 10. NUMISMATIC PUBLIC ENTERPRISE FUND. Coins issued under this Act are subject to provisions of the Numismatic Public Enterprise Fund. SEC. 11. FINANCIAL ASSURANCES. The coin program should be self-sustaining with no net cost to the Fund.
